hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of a linked list. Each node has a value and a pointer to the next node. Make sure you can visualize how nodes are connected.
Consider the base cases: What will you return if the linked list is empty or has only one node? Think about how these cases can be handled before proceeding with the swapping logic.
To swap nodes in pairs, you'll need to keep track of the current node and the next node. How can you use pointers to achieve this? Consider using a temporary variable to help with the swapping.
Think about how you can iterate through the list. You could use a loop that processes two nodes at a time. What condition will help you determine when to stop iterating?
When swapping two nodes, you'll need to adjust the pointers of the nodes involved. Remember to update the 'next' pointers correctly to maintain the list structure after the swap.
Consider using a dummy node at the beginning of your linked list. This can simplify edge cases, especially when swapping the head of the list. How will this affect your pointer updates?
As you swap nodes, ensure that you are not losing track of the rest of the list. After swapping a pair, how will you connect the swapped nodes to the next pair?
Make sure to test your solution with various cases, including an empty list, a list with one node, and a list with an odd number of nodes. What should happen in each case?
After you have swapped the nodes in pairs, remember to return the new head of the list. If you used a dummy node, how will you determine the new head?
You are very close! Try writing the code for swapping the first two nodes and then use a loop to continue swapping the rest of the nodes. Make sure to handle the pointers correctly.

questionNotes: Constraints: The number of nodes in the list is in the range [0, 100].
Return the head of the modified list after swapping nodes in pairs.
Do not modify the values in the nodes; only the nodes themselves may be changed.
